title: Chuck Locke
text:
Charles Edward Locke (May 5, 1932 – January 9, 2015) was an American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> player. Locke was a right-handed <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> who appeared in two <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> <a href="games%20played">games</a> for the <a href="Baltimore%20Orioles">Baltimore Orioles</a>, and although he allowed no <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hits</a> or <a href="run%20%28baseball%29">runs</a> in three total <a href="inning%20%28baseball%29">innings</a> of work as a <a href="relief%20pitcher">reliever</a>, he never again pitched in the Majors.
Locke, who stood tall and weighed , spent nine years (1950–1958) in professional baseball; all but four games were played in the Baltimore organization. He signed with the franchise in 1950 when it was still the <a href="St.%20Louis%20Browns">St. Louis Browns</a> and was recalled by the Orioles in 1955 after he won 18 games for the <a href="San%20Antonio%20Missions">San Antonio Missions</a> of the Double-A <a href="Texas%20League">Texas League</a>.
In his MLB debut, at <a href="Memorial%20Stadium%20%28Baltimore%29">Memorial Stadium</a> against the <a href="Washington%20Senators%20%281901%E2%80%9360%29">Washington Senators</a>, he came into the game in the eighth inning with Baltimore trailing, 7–4. Locke allowed one baserunner, on an <a href="error%20%28baseball%29">error</a>, but got out of the inning unscathed when <a href="Eddie%20Yost">Eddie Yost</a>'s <a href="Batted%20ball">fly ball</a> resulted in a 9–6–5 <a href="double%20play">double play</a>. He left for a <a href="pinch%20hitter">pinch hitter</a> in the bottom of the eighth, when the Orioles rallied to tie the game — which they went on to win, 8–7.
In his second and final appearance a week later, also against the Senators (but at <a href="Griffith%20Stadium">Griffith Stadium</a>), Locke pitched the last two innings of a 7–3 Oriole defeat. He retired Washington in order in the seventh, and in the eighth recorded his only Major League <a href="strikeout">strikeout</a> (Yost) and <a href="base%20on%20balls">base on balls</a> (<a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Valdivielso">José Valdivielso</a>).
Locke returned to <a href="minor%20league%20baseball">minor league baseball</a> in 1956 and retired after the 1958 season after 274 minor league games and an 82–97 <a href="Win%E2%80%93loss%20record%20%28pitching%29">won–lost record</a>.
